headline.main: Adolescent Obesity Linked to Adult Ailments

docs.lead_paragraph: Being overweight during the teen-age years can lead to life-threatening chronic disease in adulthood, even if the youngster later sheds the excess weight, according to new findings from a study spanning more than 60 years. The study indicated that adolescent obesity was even more strongly linked to health risks than being overweight in adult life. The lasting effects of teen-age obesity were most pronounced among boys. Those in the top 25 percent of weight in relation to their height were found to be more likely than leaner boys to suffer fatal heart attacks, strokes, colon cancer and other health problems before their 70th birthdays.
